DhyÄna Chapter, Unasked Section, DhyÄna Chapter 9 If the conditions are complete, one can attain concentration, but if the conditions are incomplete, one cannot attain concentration.

Cultivating concentration has such conditions, namely, a bhiká¹£u who protects the precepts of liberation, achieves the practice of dignified deportment, in places where he has already practiced, protects the subtle precepts as if fearing a diamond, upholds the precepts, cuts off wrong livelihood and practices right livelihood, has good friends, good companions, and a good assembly, controls the sense doors, knows moderation in food and drink, diligently practices without initial sleep, and avoids obstructive dharmas.

Thus, a bhiká¹£u knows to eliminate the five hindrances, the defilements of the mind that weaken wisdom, and to be free from sensual desire, evil and unwholesome states, with initial and sustained thought, joy and happiness, to accomplish the practice of the first meditation, up to eliminating suffering and happiness, and before the cessation of joy and sorrow, with pure equanimity and mindfulness, to accomplish the practice of the fourth meditation.
What is the precept of protecting liberation?

If one follows the precepts and does not act carelessly, using the precepts as a door, as a foot, as a cause, one can give rise to wholesome dharmas and fully accomplish them. Because of these precepts, it is called upholding the precepts.
Because of this, following non-carelessness is called upholding the precepts and protecting dignified conduct. This is called the precept of protecting liberation.
What is accomplishing dignified conduct?
All unwholesome bodily actions, all unwholesome verbal actions, and all unwholesome mental actions are called undignified conduct.
All wholesome bodily actions, all wholesome verbal actions, and all wholesome mental actions are called the accomplishment of dignified conduct.
Moreover, respecting one's teacher and fellow students, respecting one's preceptor and fellow students, and respecting those above and below oneself, this is called dignified conduct.
What is a place one has already gone to?
There are six places one has not yet gone to, namely the places of prostitutes, widows, young girls, eunuchs, nuns, and liquor sellers. These are called the six places one has not yet gone to.
Furthermore, as the Buddha said:
Monks!
Do not go to other countries that are not places you have already gone to.
If you go to other countries that are not places you have already gone to, Mara will find an opportunity.
Monks!
What are called other countries that are not places you have already gone to?
They refer to the five desires.
This is called going to the five desires that are not places you have already gone to.
What is a place one has already gone to?

If one does not engage in improper conduct, and this is not a place one has already gone to, abandoning, correctly abandoning, abandoning as a condition, not associating with, correctly not associating with, associating with as a condition, this is called a place one has already gone to.
Moreover, as the Buddha said:
One should practice in one's own country and in places one has already gone to. If a bhiká¹£u practices in his own country and in places he has already gone to, MÄra will find no opportunity.
Bhiká¹£us!
What is meant by one's own country and places one has already gone to?
It refers to the four establishments of mindfulness.
This is one's own country and places one has already gone to.
If one engages in this proper conduct, arouses, correctly arouses, receives, correctly receives, this is called the accomplishment of proper conduct and places one has already gone to.
What is meant by guarding the subtle precepts as if fearing adamantine?

If one is mindful of subtle precepts, arouses the intention to practice, desires to practice together, and arouses many fears towards them, thinking May I not violate them, this is called fearing the subtle precepts as if they were adamantine.
What is meant by upholding the precepts?

If a bhiká¹£u does not abandon any precepts, always upholds all precepts, always abides in all precepts, is close to the precepts, upholds the precepts without flaw, without defilement, without stain, without laziness, without deficiency, and upholds all precepts, this is called upholding the precepts.
What is abandoning wrong livelihood and practicing right livelihood?
What is wrong livelihood?

If Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as make a living through wrong livelihood, such as flattery, falsely claiming to have spiritual powers, divining good and bad fortune, acting as messengers for others, making exaggerated claims, seeking profit through profit, and using these unwholesome means to obtain robes, alms bowl, medicine, bedding, and other necessities for use and consumption, becoming attached to these, being greedy, despising others, tolerating unwholesome behavior, not seeing the faults, and not knowing how to transcend the world.

If a bhiká¹£u, having abandoned such wrong livelihoods, obtains robes, alms, medicine, and bedding as needed through proper means, and uses them without being bound, attached, and greedy, without despising others, unable to endure what is improper, deeply seeing the faults, and knowing what transcends the world, this is called abandoning wrong livelihood and practicing right livelihood.
What is a good friend?

It refers to Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who uphold the precepts, are virtuous, have abandoned arrogance and indulgence, have accomplished patience, have disciplined themselves, extinguished themselves, and entered nirvÄá¹‡a themselves, who wish to be free from desire, to exhaust desire, up to being free from delusion and exhausting delusion, who are not deluded in places where one should not be deluded, up to not being deluded in places where one should be deluded, who do not stop where one should stop, who do not accept where one should accept, whose bodily, verbal, and mental actions are pure, whose right livelihood is pure, who practice faith, shame, and scruples, who are diligent in learning, energetic, mindful, and practice wisdom, who are endowed with the eight factors, namely precepts, concentration, wisdom, liberation, the knowledge and vision of liberation, and whose robes and food are sufficient. This is called a good friend.
What is meant by knowledge?

If one knows and recognizes the practice of loving-kindness, the repeated practice of loving-kindness, the ultimate practice of loving-kindness, always respecting and not being apart from it, this is called good knowledge.
What is a good friend?

An ordinary person who upholds the precepts is a good friend for an ordinary person who upholds the precepts. A person of firm faith is a good friend for a person of firm faith. A person of firm practice is a good friend for a person of firm practice. Up to an arhat is a good friend for an arhat.
In this way, one's own close friends are called friends.
If a good friend or a good close friend follows and does not leave, and is intimate, this is called a good friend and a good close friend.
What is a good assembly?

If one relies on those who uphold precepts and learns to uphold precepts, one's mind turns towards them, respects them, inclines towards them, and understands them. If one relies on those in concentration and learns concentration, up to those who have the knowledge and vision of liberation, one learns the knowledge and vision of liberation, one's mind turns towards them, respects them, inclines towards them, and understands them. This is called the good assembly.
What is meant by guarding the sense doors?

If a bhiká¹£u sees forms with the eye, he does not grasp at the characteristics of forms, and is able to restrain the eye faculty, being heedful and not negligent, cutting off unwholesome and unskillful dharmas and worldly desires and hopes, following the precepts, and guarding the eye faculty, attaining the precepts of the eye faculty.

Up to the mind cognizing dharmas with the mind, he does not grasp at the characteristics of dharmas, and is able to restrain the mind faculty, being heedful and not negligent, cutting off unwholesome and unskillful dharmas and worldly desires and hopes, following the precepts, and guarding the mind faculty.

In this way, with regard to the six sense bases, he protects the subtle mindfulness, understands the well-accomplished practice of mindfulness in archery, sees the faults of desire, and always guards his mind. This is called guarding the sense doors.
What is knowing moderation in food?

Eating in moderation, not being agitated, not being arrogant, not for nourishing the body, not for adorning the body, but only for the sake of comfort, not giving rise to anger, wishing to cultivate the holy life, to end old feelings and not give rise to new feelings, for the sake of livelihood.
Abandoning hatred and love, always abiding in the middle way, not seeking gain, diligently practicing with joy.
Just as a person with a wound applies medicine to it in order to heal it.
So it is with a bhiká¹£u, knowing moderation in food, not being agitated, not being arrogant, up to not seeking gain, diligently practicing with joy.
What is agitated food?
If one thinks like this:
After eating this food, I will act in a way that agitates body, speech, and mind.
This is called agitated food.
What is arrogant food?
If one thinks like this:
After eating this food, I will increase my negligence.
This is called arrogant food.
What is nourishing the body food?
If one thinks:
After eating this food, I will benefit my body.
This is called nourishing the body food.
What is adornment food?
If one thinks:
After eating this food, I will be upright, beautiful, and have perfect features.
This is called adornment food.
If a bhiká¹£u does not think like this:
After eating this food, I will be frivolous in body, speech, and mind, I will be arrogant, I will nourish my body, I will adorn my body.
This is called non-frivolous food, non-arrogant, non-nourishing the body, non-adornment food.
What is meant by just wanting to sustain the body?
One should think like this:
After eating this food, I just want to sustain my body, not to end or perish.
This is called just wanting to sustain the body.
What is meant by not giving rise to anger?ğŸ”½If one is hungry, because of hunger, one gives rise to physical and mental suffering.
If one overeats, because of overeating, one gives rise to physical and mental suffering.
If a bhiká¹£u eats with contentment and reflects well on his food, then anger will be extinguished, not arising or occurring.
This is called not giving rise to anger.
What is meant by wishing to cultivate pure conduct?
Pure conduct refers to the Eightfold Noble Path.
One should think like this:
Having eaten this food, I will be able to cultivate pure conduct, causing pure conduct to endure for a long time, and to end suffering.
This is called wishing to cultivate pure conduct.
What is meant by cutting off old feelings and not giving rise to new feelings?
If one is hungry, and because of hunger, physical and mental feelings of suffering arise, this is called old feelings.
What are new feelings?
If one eats excessively, and because of excessive eating, physical and mental feelings of suffering arise, this is called new feelings.
If a bhiká¹£u eats with contentment and reflects well on his food, this is called cutting off old feelings and not giving rise to new feelings.
What is meant by eating for the sake of staying alive?
One should think like this:
I eat this food in order to sustain the life faculty and to uphold the precepts.
This is called eating for the sake of staying alive.
What is meant by abandoning the vajra of aversion and desire?
If one is hungry and the arising of afflictions of desire due to hunger, one should recollect:
I dislike such food.
If one eats too much and the arising of afflictions of aversion due to overeating, one should not recollect such excessive eating.
If a bhiká¹£u is content and eats in moderation, abandoning the afflictions of aversion and desire, this is called abandoning the vajra of aversion and desire.
What is meant by not seeking gain?
If one is not content with coarse food and eats a lot, indulges in flavors and craves flavors, and diligently seeks and hopes for food and drink, this is called seeking gain.

If a bhiká¹£u is content with coarse food and eats in moderation, does not indulge in flavors, does not crave flavors, does not diligently seek, and does not hope for food and drink, this is called not seeking gain.
What is meant by exertion?
If one thinks like this:
I eat this food in order to exert myself physically and strive for self-improvement.
This is called diligence.
What is meant by pleasant practice?
If one is hungry and experiences physical and mental suffering due to hunger, or if one overeats and experiences physical and mental suffering due to overeating, this is called unpleasant.
If a bhiká¹£u is content and well-considered in eating, there is no unpleasantness. This is called pleasant practice.
What is meant by being diligent and not sleeping?
If a bhiká¹£u during the day either sits in meditation with crossed legs and contemplates, or walks back and forth, with a mind free from obstructive dharmas,
in the first watch of the night, either walks back and forth or contemplates, with a mind free from obstructive dharmas,
in the middle of the night, lies on the right side with the feet placed on top of each other, and sleeps while contemplating the thought of rising,
in the last watch of the night, either contemplates or walks back and forth, with a mind free from obstructive dharmas.
This is called being diligent and not sleeping.
What is meant by being free from obstructive dharmas?
Obstructive dharmas refer to the five hindrances.
As the Buddha said:
The five hindrances are mental afflictions that trouble the mind and harm the Dharma of wisdom.
Moreover, the Buddha explained next:

If laypeople or renunciants have their minds covered by the five hindrances, whether they know the meaning for themselves, know the meaning for others, or know the meaning for both self and others, whether they have superhuman abilities, or know and see through the abandonment of desire, it is impossible.
The five hindrances obstruct wholesome dharmas, bind and defile, and give rise to afflictions, so they are called hindrances.
If one cultivates purity and removes the dharmas of hindrances, it becomes pure and clear, which is called the dharma of being free from hindrances.
How does one eliminate the five hindrances?
To be free from, to extinguish, to submerge, and to remove them, this is called eliminating the five hindrances.
What is mental defilement?
The five hindrances are mental afflictions, defiled and unclear, which is called mental defilement.
How does one harm the dharma of wisdom?
The five hindrances cover the mind, and the power of wisdom is weak, which is called harming the dharma of wisdom.
How does one abandon desire and unwholesome dharmas?
Desire refers to the five desires.
Furthermore, the objects are not desire. In the noble Dharma, they are called guá¹‡a.
If one recollects and becomes attached to them, this is desire.
As the Buddha said:
Various forms are not desire, sentient beings are attached to the desire of form;
The form in the world is permanent, the strong one is free from the attachment of desire.
If one strongly desires, endures, and clings to these five desires, this is called desire.
What are unwholesome dharmas?
Evil deeds of body, speech, and mind are called unwholesome dharmas.
Furthermore, the ten unwholesome courses of action are called unwholesome dharmas.

Furthermore, dharmas associated with the roots of unwholesomeness, dharmas arisen from the roots of unwholesomeness, dharmas without conditions, and dharmas not to be experienced are called unwholesome dharmas.

Furthermore, greed, anger, delusion, resentment, spite, lying, jealousy, stinginess, flattery, deceit, concealing evil, shamelessness, lack of conscience, arrogance, disputes, and conceit, etc., are called unwholesome dharmas.

Furthermore, wrong views, wrong thoughts, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong concentration, wrong liberation, wrong knowledge, and other deviant dharmas, are called evil and unwholesome dharmas.

Thus, if one is far away from, does not approach, is not mixed with, is pure, and is in a separate place from evil and unwholesome dharmas, this is called being free from evil and unwholesome dharmas.
What is meant by with initial and sustained thought?
If there is initial and sustained thought in practice, this is called with initial and sustained thought.
What is meant by joy and pleasure born of seclusion?
If joy and pleasure are born from being free from evil and unwholesome dharmas, this is called joy and pleasure born of seclusion.
What is meant by accomplishing the practice of the first meditation?
The first meditation has five factors:
initial and sustained thought, joy, pleasure, and one-pointedness of mind.
What is meant by initial thought?
Repeated thought and ultimate thought, all the clearly remembered dharmas that come to the mind for contemplation, are called initial thought.
What is meant by sustained thought?
Mental activity, following, subtle activity, mental flow, subtle observation, and subtle mental transformation are called contemplation.
What is joy?
To be joyful and elated is called joy.
What is pleasure?
To experience pleasure in the mind and pleasant feelings from mental contact is called pleasure.
What is one-pointedness of mind?
For the mind to abide and be rightly established is called one-pointedness of mind.
These five factors are called the first dhyÄna.
What is meant by first?
If these four dhyÄnas are in sequence, not contrary, and enter the concentration gate in sequence, this is the beginning, this is the first, this is the one, it is called the first.
What is meant by dhyÄna?
It means to abandon the defilements of the mind, to be rightly equanimous, and to be equanimous towards conditions. This is called dhyÄna.
Moreover, it is called dhyÄna because it can cut off the afflictions that have not yet been cut off.
Moreover, it is called dhyÄna because one attains the practice of present-life bliss after cutting off the afflictions.
Moreover, it is called dhyÄna because one accomplishes such wholesome dharmas, enters dhyÄna, and is clear, radiant, and pure.
Furthermore, to abide in this way in the profound and wondrous meaning, and to be solely attached to wisdom, is called dhyÄna.

Furthermore, when a practitioner practices contemplation and discernment, with a joyful mind and concentration, as when a practitioner experiences perception, conception, contemplation, views, wisdom, liberation, non-delusion, faith-delight, mental joy, mental exertion, mental purification, faith, desire, heedfulness, mindfulness, equanimity, the mind-element, the mind-consciousness element, and the other accompanying forms, this is called dhyÄna.
Furthermore, the dharmas that accord with dhyÄna are not dhyÄna itself, but the dharmas that accord with dhyÄna. If the mind abides and abides correctly, this is called dhyÄna.
Having attained this concentration, to maintain the dignified deportment and abide in the subtle practice, this is called accomplishing the practice of the first dhyÄna.
If a bhiká¹£u's body is fully suffused with the moisture of joy born of separation, this body is fully suffused with the moisture of joy born of separation without decrease.

Just as a good bath master or a disciple of a good bath master, with fine bath powder placed in a vessel, sprinkles water on it and adjusts it appropriately to make a paste, this paste is moist and full, neither dry nor wet, and is smooth both inside and out.
In the same way, a bhiká¹£u, with this body filled with the joy and pleasure born of separation, is without deficiency.ğŸ”½What is meant by moist?
What is meant by full?ğŸ”½What is meant by pervading?
What is meant by filling?

When a bhiká¹£u abides in dhyÄna, the joy and pleasure born of separation arises, is being born, is arising, is being produced, and he experiences with the body the joy and pleasure born of separation. At that time, it is called moist.ğŸ”½When abiding in dhyÄna, the joy and pleasure born of separation gradually opens up and functions subtly, but has not yet increased and expanded, and the body experiences the joy and pleasure born of separation. At that time, it is called full.

When abiding in dhyÄna, the joy and pleasure born of separation is able to increase and expand, but has not yet reached the other shore, and the body experiences the joy and pleasure born of separation. At that time, it is called pervading.

When abiding in meditation, one can attain the other shore with the joy and pleasure born of separation. This is called the joy and pleasure born of separation in the body, and at that time it is said to be fulfilled.

It is like a farmer first irrigating the fields with water. The initial moistening is called moistening. After moistening, the water gradually opens up and flows, but it is not yet able to increase and spread, so it is called liquid. After the liquid, the water gradually increases and spreads, but it has not yet reached the other shore, so it is called pervasive. After pervasiveness, the water reaches the other shore and fills all the high and low places. When it is full, the water pushes back against the water source, so it is called full.

The bhiká¹£u is also like this. When abiding in meditation, the joy and pleasure born of separation first arises, is being born, is arising, and is being produced, and one touches and experiences the joy and pleasure born of separation in the body. At that time, it is called moistening.ğŸ”½The joy and pleasure born of separation gradually opens up and flows, but it is not yet able to increase and spread. The joy and pleasure born of separation in the body, at that time, is called liquid.

The joy and pleasure born of separation is able to increase and spread, but has not yet reached the other shore. The joy and pleasure born of separation in the body, at that time, is called pervasive.
The joy and pleasure born of separation can reach the other shore. This is called the joy and pleasure born of separation. At that time, the body is said to be filled.
Next, the phrases pervades and fills have the same meaning but different words.
As the Buddha said:
What is called awakening?
If one awakens, awakens again, and ultimately awakens, and all the remembered dharmas become clear, come to the mind, and are contemplated in the mind, this is called awakening.
Bhiká¹£us!
This meaning should not be spoken of in this way.

Awakening is different, awakening again is different, ultimate awakening is different, all the remembered dharmas are different, becoming clear is different, coming to the mind is different, and contemplating in the mind is different.
Just as the meaning of the phrase awakening has the same meaning but different words, pervades and fills also have the same meaning but different words.

Just as when a bhiká¹£u cultivates a mind of loving-kindness, pervading the east, south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above and below, with a mind of loving-kindness, vast, exalted, immeasurable, without enmity, without ill will, pervading the entire world with a mind of loving-kindness, at that time he takes sentient beings as his object.
In the same way, when a bhiká¹£u's body is filled with the joy and bliss born of separation, at that time he takes the body as his object.
One should not speak like this.

Just as when a bhiká¹£u should contemplate impermanence, separate from desires and unwholesome states, with applied thought and sustained thought, joy and happiness, and accomplish the practice of the first meditation, then the joy and bliss born of separation pervades.

Having attained the joy and bliss born of separation in the body, he removes the burning of the body and mind, the heat of the body and mind, the fever of the body and mind, the burning of the body and mind, the scorching of the body and mind, the evil of the body and mind, the unhappiness of the body and mind, the lack of ease of the body and mind, the lack of lightness of the body and mind, the lack of warmth of the body and mind, the lack of removal of the body and mind.

Just as a bhiká¹£u removes burning of the body, burning of the mind, and so on, up to not removing the body, not removing the mind, and then attains non-burning of the body, non-warmth, non-heat, non-burning, and non-charring of the body, and attains bliss, then there is no affliction, no seeking of gain, and joyfully practices with diligent effort. This is called the bliss of separation arising and pervading the body.
What is the cessation of initial and sustained thought?
If initial and sustained thought is tranquil, well-tranquil, ceased, subsided, and removed, this is called the cessation of initial and sustained thought.
What is internal clarity of faith?
Internally there is faith, right faith arises, and it is fully accomplished. This is called internal clarity of faith.
What is single-pointedness of mind?
The mind abides alone, abides rightly, abides alone in the right place, and enters concentration. This is called single-pointedness of mind.
What is without initial thought and sustained thought?
If, having removed initial and sustained thought, the mind is concentrated, and one fully accomplishes the bliss of joy, this is called without initial thought and sustained thought.
What is the accomplishment of the practice of the second concentration, which is born from concentration, joy, and bliss?
What is the second concentration?
The second dhyÄna has four factors:
inner purity, joy, bliss, and single-pointedness of mind.
What is inner purity?

If a bhiká¹£u, having separated from desires, separated from evil and unwholesome dharmas, endowed with investigation and analysis, dwells having attained the joy and bliss born of separation, practicing the first dhyÄna,
as the bhiká¹£u contemplates that investigation and analysis are coarse, that his investigation and analysis are coarse, and that inner purity is tranquil and excellent.

The bhiká¹£u, having contemplated that investigation and analysis are coarse, with the cessation of investigation and analysis, tranquil and well-tranquilized, having abandoned and extinguished investigation and analysis, tranquil and well-tranquilized, having abandoned and extinguished them, is endowed with and dwells having attained inner purity, this is called inner purity.

As the bhiká¹£u, whether by practice, by receiving instruction, by the characteristics of the Dharma, by skillful means, by single-mindedness, by contemplation, or by contact, having separated from desires, separated from evil and unwholesome dharmas, endowed with investigation and analysis, dwells having attained the joy and bliss born of separation, practicing the first dhyÄna,
Just as a bhiká¹£u practices, if he receives the teachings and cultivates them closely and extensively, his mind will incline towards tranquility, respect tranquility, and tend towards tranquility.

Having inclined his mind towards tranquility, respected tranquility, and tended towards tranquility, his thoughts and contemplations will be tranquil, correctly tranquil, extinguished, submerged, eliminated, and exhausted.

Having extinguished thoughts and contemplations, being correctly tranquil, extinguished, submerged, eliminated, and exhausted, pure faith arises within him, and he fully accomplishes it. This is called pure faith within.ğŸ”½Furthermore, the bhiká¹£u contemplates that thoughts and contemplations are coarse dharmas, and the mind is purified by eliminating coarse dharmas. The purified mind is called pure faith within.ğŸ”½Furthermore, the bhiká¹£u contemplates that thoughts and contemplations are coarse dharmas, and the mind is pure and bright by separating from coarse dharmas. The pure and bright mind is called pure faith within.

Furthermore, the bhiká¹£u contemplates that thoughts and contemplations are coarse dharmas, and the mind is clear and distinct by eliminating coarse dharmas. The clear and distinct mind is called pure faith within.

Furthermore, a bhiká¹£u contemplates that the state of having initial and sustained thought is coarse, while the state without initial thought and sustained thought is tranquil and sublime. This is called internal purity of faith.

Furthermore, a bhiká¹£u contemplates that with initial and sustained thought, the mind is not pliant, not tranquil, not pure, not clear, and not clear and bright, while without initial thought and sustained thought, the mind is pliant, tranquil, pure, clear, and clear and bright.
The mind being pliant up to clear and bright, this is called internal purity of faith.

Furthermore, a bhiká¹£u contemplates that in the state without initial thought and sustained thought, the mind is joyful and concentrated, just as a practitioner, whether joyfully believing, entering belief, ultimately entering belief, with superior belief, and pure belief, with a mind of belief, this is called internal purity of faith.
What is called joy?
Like a practitioner who is joyful and elated, this is called joy.
What is called pleasure?
Like a practitioner who experiences bodily pleasure and mental pleasure, this is called pleasure.
What is called one-pointedness of mind?
Like a practitioner whose mind believes in the right Dharma, this is called one-pointedness of mind.
These four factors are called the second dhyÄna.
What is meant by second?
Following the sequence of the four dhyÄnas, without going against it, one enters samÄdhi in sequence. There is nothing in between the second and the first. This is called second.
What is meant by dhyÄna?
DhyÄna refers to the mind of equanimity, right equanimity, and conditioned equanimity. This is called dhyÄna.

Furthermore, it refers to the practice of being without initial and sustained thought, mental joy, and concentration. If a practitioner experiences perception, conception, intention, contact, and volition, and so forth, and the corresponding form, this is called dhyÄna.
Furthermore, the dharmas that accord with but are not dhyÄna are the dharmas that accord with dhyÄna. If the mind abides and abides correctly, this is called dhyÄna.
Having attained this samÄdhi, one protects and upholds the dignified deportment, abiding and practicing the subtle practices. This is called accomplishing the practice of the second dhyÄna.
If a bhiká¹£u generates the joy and bliss of samÄdhi, and it completely fills this body, the joy and bliss generated by samÄdhi completely fills it without deficiency.

Just as a large pond surrounded by mountains, the water wells up from the bottom and does not come from the east, south, west, or north, but wells up from the bottom, filling the pond with water without any decrease.
In the same way, a bhiká¹£u's body concentration gives rise to joy and pleasure, filling it without any decrease.ğŸ”½What is meant by filling?
What is meant by moistening?ğŸ”½What is meant by pervading?

What is meant by satiation?ğŸ”½When a bhiká¹£u dwells in meditation and the body concentration gives rise to joy and pleasure, generating and arising, touching and realizing, the body concentration gives rise to joy and pleasure, at that time it is called filling.ğŸ”½When a bhiká¹£u dwells in meditation and the body concentration gradually opens up and subtly functions, but has not yet increased and expanded, the body concentration gives rise to joy and pleasure, at that time it is called moistening.

When a bhiká¹£u dwells in meditation and the body concentration is able to increase and expand, but has not yet reached the other shore, the concentration gives rise to joy and pleasure, at that time it is called pervading.

When abiding in meditation, the joy and bliss born from concentration can reach the other shore. This is called the joy and bliss born from concentration. At that time, it is said that the body is filled.

It is like a farmer first irrigating the fields with water, initially moistening them. At that time, it is called moistening.ğŸ”½After being moistened, the water gradually opens up and flows, but it has not yet increased and expanded. At that time, it is called liquid.
